placement/tests/functional/test_allocati.message: this is a module global, so each test case will use the same consumer uuid and as test can be run parallel this can cause that they interfere

I know this is horrid but after much struggling I was still at a loss how else to reproduce the issue without masking the real bug with database lock timeout errors. If anyone knows a better way to do this, feel free to change this or let me know and I can change it.

One way to avoid multiprocessing is to simulate the race a bit differently.

As far as I see all three codepath calls placement.handlers.allocation._resource_providers_by_uuid() to collect the current RP information including generation _before_ goes into replace_all(). 

What if we simulate the race not by bumping the RP generation after the RP was read by the normal codepath, but instead wrap placement.handlers.allocation._resource_providers_by_uuid() to return the RPs with RP.generation - 1. So when the normal codepath in _set_allocation compares the request data with the DB date, it will see a "newer" generation and fail with conflict, then we can let the normal codepath to re-try and succeed.

Nope ^^ does not work. As with this logic the first RP read (the one we are wrapping) and the subsequent re-reads in the retry returns different RP.generation values regardless of the transaction isolation. So this way the problem cannot be reproduced.

ironic/tests/unit/db/sqlalchemy/test_mig.message:
the ".execute" method/symbol goes away from insert() entirely.  Also, always use the context manager when connecting so that the connection is released at the end of its use.  heres how this function should be written:

    def _check_3bea56f25597(self, engine, data):
        nodes = db_utils.get_table(self.engine, 'nodes')
        instance_uuid = 'aaaaaaaa-bbbb-cccc-dddd-eeeeeeeeeeee'
        data = {'driver': 'fake',
                'uuid': uuidutils.generate_uuid(),
                'instance_uuid': instance_uuid}
        with self.engine.begin() as connection:
            insert_node = nodes.insert().values(data)
            connection.execute(insert_node)
            data['uuid'] = uuidutils.generate_uuid()
            self.assertRaises(db_exc.DBDuplicateEntry,
                                connection.execute, nodes.insert(), data)

above uses begin() because we are executing DML and we will want to avoid a particular SQLAlchemy 2.0 deprecation warning regarding "autocommit".   connection.execute is then the only "execute()" method so that includes in the assertion.

this kind of change will need to be made all over the place so it's not necessarily a trivial migration.

this part is still incorrect, should be:

   self.assertRaises(db_exc.DBDuplicateEntry,
                                connection.execute, nodes.insert(), data)

just a note, the most direct translation of this from the previous code would be:

   insert_node = nodes.insert()
   connection.execute(insert_node, data_node)

however using .values() explicitly is fine in this case as well, it would have a different execution style if data_node were a list of dictionaries but that's not the case here.

deployment/glance/glance-api-container-p.message:
The description sounds plausibly accurate, but I feel like something is missing that would allow the user to answer two critical (IMHO) questions;

1. What does a self-reference URL look like? Do you have an example?
2. Under what circumstances should it be set?

Maybe this patch isn't the best place to answer the questions, but the whole thing is rather mysterious. I see how this patch will emit hiera data that gets consumed by glance::api, but I have no idea what to do with this feature.

Thanks, Dan, this is extremely helpful!

I gather the purpose is to configure each glance worker (i.e. node where g-api is running) to know **its own** internal API URL, so that it can share it with other workers to ensure the correct worker handles a distributed image import.

Therefore, we don't want the user to set value. Instead, tripleo should automatically configure the "correct" value for *each* node. I believe the way to do that is
- Eliminate the GlanceWorkerSelfReferenceUrl THT parameter
- Change L469 to something like this (similar to what we do here [1]):

            glance::api::worker_self_reference_url:
              if:
              - internal_tls_enabled
              - str_replace:
                  template:
                    "https://%{hiera('fqdn_NETWORK')}:9292"
                  params:
                    NETWORK: {get_param: [ServiceNetMap, GlanceApiNetwork]}
              - str_replace:
                  template:
                    "http://%{hiera('NETWORK_uri')}:9292"
                  params:
                    NETWORK: {get_param: [ServiceNetMap, GlanceApiNetwork]}

Does that sound right?

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/branch/master/deployment/glance/glance-api-edge-container-puppet.yaml#L52

I would tend to think that for something like tripleo, we would never really expect "the user" to set this, but that we should just be able to generate and set it from everything else we know, right? Do we ask/allow the user to change the list of URLs to be balanced in the haxproxy config?

The URL just needs to point to the worker's HTTP API directly, bypassing any load balancer. It's used so that a glance worker can hit the HTTP API of another worker directly, without going through any balancing. Basically, we know worker 17 (random number) has the image staged, so we need to specifically talk to that worker to tell it to go. If we just go through the LB, then we'll get directed to some other worker, which won't work.

You can look at devstack for an example when we configure this on:

https://github.com/openstack/devstack/blob/master/lib/glance#L365

In devstack, we have apache sitting in front of uwsgi to provide SSL termination and make the services show up as resources underneath a common http(s) server. In that case, everything is running on the same machine, so we just set the self-reference URL to the direct uwsgi HTTP port for each worker.

I would expect that for you, glance-api on every machine is given a specific port, and that we write some haproxy configuration listing each node as a URL, with its address and port for haproxy to balance. So, it's those URLs that we need, each node configured to know what URL reaches it directly.

This is also described in the docs, with examples:

https://docs.openstack.org/glance/latest/admin/interoperable-image-import.html#staging-directory-configuration

and in the spec:

https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/glance-specs/specs/wallaby/approved/glance/distributed-image-import.html

...in case those help.

If it's still not clear, let me know and we can drill down some more.

> I gather the purpose is to configure each glance worker (i.e. node where g-api is running) to know **its own** internal API URL, so that it can share it with other workers to ensure the correct worker handles a distributed image import.

Exactly.

> Therefore, we don't want the user to set value. Instead, tripleo should automatically configure the "correct" value for *each* node. I believe the way to do that is
> - Eliminate the GlanceWorkerSelfReferenceUrl THT parameter
> - Change L469 to something like this (similar to what we do here [1]):
> 
>             glance::api::worker_self_reference_url:
>               if:
>               - internal_tls_enabled
>               - str_replace:
>                   template:
>                     "https://%{hiera('fqdn_NETWORK')}:9292"
>                   params:
>                     NETWORK: {get_param: [ServiceNetMap, GlanceApiNetwork]}
>               - str_replace:
>                   template:
>                     "http://%{hiera('NETWORK_uri')}:9292"
>                   params:
>                     NETWORK: {get_param: [ServiceNetMap, GlanceApiNetwork]}
> 
> Does that sound right?

Yep, I think it'd be much better if the user _can't_ set this, because it's likely they could only break things. The only case I can think of would be if this is running a glance at a distributed site, which is behind some sort of reverse proxy thing or something and needs to be different. However, I expect that'd break other things and/or not be possible without hand-editing stuff anyway, so probably not a concern.
Is there a reason you can't just use {get_param: [EndpointMap, GlanceInternal, uri_no_suffix]}

well, this makes sense to use available information in heat is good to use avoid depending on puppet hieradata. Will update it in next patch set.

Sorry for the delay in reply.

build-tools/stx/aptly_deb_usage.py.message:
where is this 60 second timeout?
Looks like you check every 5 secs, but otherwise wait forever.

The 60 second timeout is set by lower level module aptly_api's Client, as a default value. We can specify it but actually, it is good for other operations but only not fit for this one. Hard to say how long it will take to sync a remote repository, so I just check it every 5 second and wait for ever. The 5 second are mainly used to let the users know it still works. Shorter sleep will cause more footprint while longer sleep will cause time waste. :-(

I think it might be wiser to add an extra parameter to enable replacement of an existing snapshot.  The parameter default to false.  If false, the command failes rather than deleting the old snapshot.

Also I wonder if there is a way to replace the snapshot in a more atomic and safe way.  i.e. how long will the snapshot be unavailable?  What if the creation of the new snapshot fails?  There is no way to restore the original snapshot!  Can snapshot's be renamed?  If es, sreate the new snapshot under a temporary name, and swap it into place of the original when ready.  I assume that would be more atomic.

Yes, aptly support rename for snapshot. But currently, for related repo, snapshot and publish, we set the same name for them. While no matter how we rename the snapshot or publish, with the original logic, there will be risks of name conflict.

For atomic, in aptly, public based on snapshot while snapshot based on repository(repo), that is the reason each time we update the content of a repo, we need to (1)delete public, (2)delete snapshot, (3)create snapshot, (4)create public. Aptly's document(https://www.aptly.info/doc/api/publish/) says the "update" method can be used for this use case. But in my test, it is not stable, sometimes it may failed. While the drop + create seems much more stable that till now no failures occurred.

Not entirely satisfied with your answer.  I still think we need a safe fallback in the event of an error, and a more atomic operation.  How long might the snapshot be unavailable, before the new one takes it's place.  If it's a shared resource, that window has to be very small.

I would be satisfied if a task or launchpad is created, and documented here, to further study the problem at a later time.

Same concerns as __create_snapshot.  

Prevent accidental deletion/overwrite, near atomic substitution when replacement is intended, and a safe fallback to the original content if we fail setting up the new content.
Thanks, I will scan all functions.
Comment says you return Bool, but code only returns None
return Bool please.  False if anything goes wrong.
Only returns None.  Probably return Bool instead.  False if anything goes wrong.
Can you also backup or rename the published snapshot, to allow for recovery if the publication of the new snapshot fails?
No, aptly doesn't support it, its public can't be renamed or backup. We have to remove + re-create it.
it appears the package is first renamed, then deleted as part of the upload process.  If this is intentional, document that in the comments.

Mocking a an external class's init method can be a bit more complex. Here's what this can be done like:


      def test_infinite_retry(self):
        retry_param = exception.ManilaException

        class FakeTenacityRetry(tenacity.Retrying):
            def __init__(*args, **kwargs):
                pass

        with mock.patch('tenacity.Retrying',
                        autospec=FakeTenacityRetry) as tenacity_retry:

            @utils.retry(retry_param=retry_param,
                         wait_random=True,
                         infinite=True)
            def some_retriable_function():
                pass

            some_retriable_function()

            tenacity_retry.assert_called_once_with(
                sleep=tenacity.nap.sleep,
                before_sleep=mock.ANY,
                after=mock.ANY,
                stop=tenacity.stop.stop_never,
                reraise=True,
                retry=utils.IsAMatcher(tenacity.retry_if_exception_type),
                wait=utils.IsAMatcher(tenacity.wait_random_exponential))

I think we should allow project admins to set quota for projects, any thoughts?

My understanding of a project admin is to manage resources for a project that affects all the users of that project.
If i take reference of default volume types, the project admin sets default type for all the users of the project and not a specific user.

Right, but the difference is that the choices of volume-type that the project-admin can choose from is set by the operator to the public volume types and any private volume types the operator has given that project access to.  So the project-admin can't do any damage.  By default, we don't want to allow arbitrary projects to increase their quotas, because that would defeat the whole point of quotas.
If they could assign quotas to users in their project, I'd agree, but we don't want a project-level admin to increase the quotas for a project independently of what the operator has set for them.
same
I feel the project admin should responsible enough to not do any such action? Else i don't see much difference between a project member and a project admin.

Think of the case where for some reason, the operator has set a quota lower than the defaults on a project.  If that project-admin could delete the quota, they would be restored to the default, which is exactly what the operator does not want.  So I think this needs to stay within system scope.

For Cinder, there isn't much difference between project-member and project-admin.  Remember that the project-admin is simply a user in a project; it's not like they're an employee of the operator in a public cloud, or report to the operator at a university.  A project-admin is simply a consumer of cloud resources.  So for Cinder, we only want a project-admin to do safe actions, if any, beyond what a project-member can do.

But remember that the personas are also implemented by Keystone, so it may be the case that a Keystone project-admin can add users to their project and assign roles to users in their project.  So that could be useful, in that the project-admin can make some users members and others readers.  But then they could also make everyone in the project an admin, too.  So we need to be very conservative about what a project-admin can do in Cinder.

That's by default, though.  If an operator wants to allow project-admins to do stuff like modify quotas, the operator can modify the Cinder policies.

This will only return all snapshots within the project, right?

Yes. The v3 URL structure is:

  {endpoint-URL}/v3/{project_id}/snapshots

which I've always taken to mean that the snapshots are a sub-resource of the project container.  (Similar for volumes, backups, etc.)  It gets weird when you have something like volume-types, where the public ones are accessible to everyone in the system, but you can still tell a story about the response from

  {endpoint-URL}/v3/{project_id}/types

giving all the volume-types accessible within that project.  It gets weird for some admin operations, though.  Also, a lot of service catalogs are configured so that the "endpoint" for the block storage API v3 is in its own service catalog object and is pre-loaded with v3 and the project_id.  In that sense, the paths specified here are misleading.  I imagine they were done like this so there wouldn't be v2/v3 duplication of basically the same path.  Now that we'll only have v3 in Wallaby, I wonder whether it's worth rewriting the paths in the DocumentedRuleDefaults to have the prefix '/v3/{project_id}' where appropriate.

How and where would the credentials be stored? I guess each httpd instance (thus each service container) will be responsible for them?
This is internal to the standalone services, so not detailed here. Yes the services use stored bcrypt hashes of the passwords on disk to authenticate. Linked reviews have the details.

I don't think noauth should be the default. I'm really not a huge fan of this proposal at al. I think removing keystone should be ok, but we still need auth for any service that isn't shut down after it's done being used.

It may not be a secure network because it's attached to compute nodes.  It's more secure with keystone auth today because the undercloud credentials are not on the overcloud nodes so even if the compute nodes get compromised they wouldn't be able to fiddle with the ironic/neutron on the undercloud.  Maybe it would be OK if we make neutron only listen on localhost?  Would probably want to run that by someone more familiar with all the compliance requirements.

As for memcache you can use 127.0.0.1 on the overcloud (and it's actually better for failures but that's another story) but that's not what the undercloud is which is why we were able to get away with hard coding it to localhost back in the instack days.

I don't think you can do that when you're using a memcached pool like in the overcloud (which is bigger risk to any current deployment). Also, I'm not saying that there are security holes and let's make some more. My contention is that ctlplane network is secure network and you think it's not. That's where we disagree. Let's leave it there.

If it's a no go, I'll see what we need to do to add basic auth for neutron.

https://github.com/openstack/instack-undercloud/blob/stable/queens/elements/puppet-stack-config/puppet-stack-config.yaml.template#L44  probably got lost in the migration to THT but yea we limited it to localhost to prevent external people from messing with it

yes, i think neutron will need the basic auth support. Neutron is not used only for IPAM due to it managing the Ironic provisioning port. It may be possible to do something evil by messing with that port's dhcp/ipxe options.

memcache isn't persistent. yes that's a vector and probably should have been secured thought I thought we limited it to localhost in previous versions. But just because we didn't secure everything in the past doesn't meant we should open up the world going forward.

> do something evil by messing with that port's dhcp/ipxe options

Are those dhcp/ipxe opt_keys relevant unless someone cleans and deploys existing nodes? We provision these ports along with the nodes with metalsmith.

From the undercloud use-case pov IMHO neutron is no more than a config-generator/config-store(like etcd) and normally don't have authentication needs in a secure network.

> we still need auth for any service that isn't shut down after it's done being used

Interesting that we're so concerned about it now. How is it different for memcached in the current architecture (bound to ctlplane ip)? Someone can surely can get a cached/long lived authtoken from the cache and mess with all the services?
well, yes: no more timeouts and headaches due to keystone. That's a thing, really!

specs/xena/noauth-undercloud.rst.message: nit: default
Worth elaborating, like a single Undercloud instance by design expects no multi-tenancy, but rather a single cloud admin to manage the deployed overcloud(s). So auth looks redundant here.
And that there is no other roles expected but admin
This adds a security problem because someone could unprovision nodes right?  How do prevent someone from being able to do things with the baremetal nodes
or do you mean Keystone auth is still required for regular users without root access on UC to control it access to APIs? Then indeed, that needs clarification.

For me, ctlplane/provisioning network should be a secured network (not for anyone to access). There are also other ways to secure the api access (ex. adding client cert auth with haproxy that we use on the undercloud by default, firewall rules etc).

I don't see any issue in having the option the deploy undercloud with noauth (It's ok if we decide not to make it default for whatever reason). There are other frameworks like Metal3 that do support 'noauth' with ironic.

Also, undercloud security is not anywhere near optimal, we store unencrypted passwords on disk, keystone tokens are valid for 4hrs (and for days for large deployments) etc etc.

AFAIK ironic-python-agent ramdisk does not have access to keystone credentials. Hence number of inspector APIs are available to unauthenticated clients. "Operators are reminded not to expose the Ironic Inspector API to unsecured and untrusted networks". So we don't lose much there.

Unfortunately, I'm not seeing any real issue other than 'it's a compliance tick'.

I believe the only safe way of dropping auth is to bind most services on 127.0.0.1, maybe make an exception for the inspector api but it would require some kind of enforcement on endpoints that can be called from localhost and endpoints that can be called from ctlplane. I don't believe it supports that kind of ACL out of the box though.

Do you mean someone can hack to the controller nodes and for that matter to an internal ctlplane network and can't do any damage atm? They can surely sniff the passwords and tokens to do whatever they want.

What is the issue in having the noauth option along with keystone? We would see for later if it would fly with end users or not.

I agree with Alex here.  Although we don't need multi-tenancy, at the very least, the current keystone auth requires that any actors be OS users that are able to read a stackrc file or otherwise have access to the admin user's credentials.  Going noauth means -
-- anyone who hacks the control plane can issue ironic commands
-- any OS user can do the same (so no auditor users or less privileged users)

Generally if you have access to the host, yea security is likely out the window. But the issue here is the fact that it's remote. And because the ctlplane is always connected to the overcloud, you're effectively opening up the noauth ironic to a much larger attack surface.  One compromised compute and someone would be able to delete the cloud if ironic is available on the undercloud's ctlplane without authentication.
if it was me, i don't want anyone with access to the host/network to be able to deprovisioning my cloud. It's a pretty big security issue.
ironic introspection needs an ironic api up on the ctlplane. not certain if auth is baked in. IMHO I don't think dropping auth is a good idea.

Who is that 'someone' we're referring to?

- If it's about access of ironic public endpoints for deployments using routable IP/hostname, then they can use keystone (We discussed about that and I've some text about it in the later sections).

- To restrict someone on the provisioning/ctlplane network, then there can be additional firewall rules.

- I would probably not worry about the OS users, as they can now run the ansible playbooks and alter the deployment.

Anyway, we will still have the option to deploy with keystone (though it's really an overhead to what we use it for in the undercloud).
Can we bind the services on localhost only? That would prevent external access.
I think we can make ironic to use http_basic along with noauth for neutron. It seems to work. That would possibly resolve your concern.

the undercloud passwords aren't on the controller. So no they can't do that.  As pointless as this is, it's usually an audit tick box for compliances.  We could do static auth instead if we don't want keystone but we need to be able to prevent unauthorized ironic from external actors.

So an external actor could issue ironic commands without authorization. I don't think that'll fly for end users.  Firewall rules will likely not be sufficient because if someone hacks the controller they'll have access to the ctlplane network. I'm not talking about OS users but rather an external actor.  Unless we restrict all services to localhost (which likely will break some things), I don't think it's OK to just disable auth.
I think Keystone authorization layer provides no extra protection comparing to root access to undercloud, which is the latter is enough to have to gain the former as well?

Ironic do support http basic auth (which we could leverage), but I don't think neutron supports it atm. With usage of tools like metalsmith (that talks to both ironic and neutron), it would be messy to support different auth types for different services.
Though I'm still not sure how a compute would be compromised in an internal network so easily, you think enabling ssl client auth in haproxy (by default) to secure the endpoints won't be good enough?

    def _validate(self, filter_properties):
        context = filter_properties['context']
        hints = filter_properties.get('scheduler_hints')

        if hints is None:
            return
        else:
            share_uuids = hints.get(self._filter_type)
            if share_uuids:
                share_uuids = share_uuids.replace('[', '').replace(']', '')
                share_uuids = share_uuids.split(",")

                filter_properties['scheduler_hints'][self._filter_type] = []

                filtered_hosts = []
                for uuid in share_uuids:
                    try:
                        share = self.share_api.get(context, uuid)
                    except exception.NotFound:
                        raise exception.ShareNotFound(uuid)
                    instances = share.get('instances')
                    if len(instances) == 0:
                        raise exception.ShareInstanceNotFound(
                            share_instance_id=uuid)
                    filtered_hosts.append(
                        [instance.get('host') for instance in instances])

                if self._filter_type == AFFINITY_FILTER:
                    filter_properties['scheduler_hints'][
                        self._filter_type] = list(
                        set.intersection(*map(set, filtered_hosts)))
                else:
                    filter_properties['scheduler_hints'][
                        self._filter_type] = list(
                        set.union(*map(set, filtered_hosts)))

                return filter_properties

tools/ovn_migration/tripleo_environment/.message: Is this because if VALIDATE_MIGRATION ==  False the migration scripts will not pre create resources prior to the migration and then this check will fail later ?

small correction to the above, OVERCLOUDRC_FILE should be set properly since it's value then used by delete-neutron-resources.sh.j2 in addition to create/delete/validate resources templates but PUBLIC_NETWORK_NAME used only in create_resources template which is skipped in case VALIDATE_MIGRATION == False.

OVN migration documentation (https://docs.openstack.org/networking-ovn/latest/install/migration.html) directs user to set VALIDATE_MIGRATION to False in case customer environment does not meet requirements regarding available FIPs. Our (RHOSP) customer tried to set VALIDATE_MIGRATION to False and received errors on generate_inventory command since it calls the oc_check_public_network function. The errors can be avoided if user specifies some additional environment variables like OVERCLOUDRC_FILE and PUBLIC_NETWORK_NAME and has spare FIPs on the public network. These environment variables are used only by the ovn_migration script and not used by the migration playbooks. Downstream CI passes with VALIDATE_MIGRATION=False but we have spare FIPs and set OVERCLOUDRC_FILE and PUBLIC_NETWORK_NAME properly.
There are some more details in RHBZ https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1997254

How could "big" network cause timeout? timeout may be caused by chunk size, no matter if it's one big network or many networks of size 100. I guess the reason for the bug is high load on physical node, or lack of hw resources. Please clarify in the bug.

Also agent step for OVS flows and RPC step are very different things. Are you hitting both types of timeouts?

If more information required please ask.

Yes, new 2 config options help to reduce timeouts, but performance suffers which is expected behavior.
Important to notice that patch does not introduce neutron performance issues.
Default values of new 2 options have the same values as hard-coded constants which were used before.
New options are additional tuning if user is not happy with default behavior.

Ok, it's more clear now, thanks.
However the two timeouts this patch is touching seem mostly affect agent restart case - when agent needs to reprocess all hosted ports. From bug description it looks the issue is with single port processing - just the amount of info needed is very big (especially if the port is first port on the node from this network) given the size of the network.

Did you managed to overcome the issue described by adjusting these 2 timeouts?
Form the bug description, this seems to be the RPC timeout. So please increase the RPC time out option to overcome large set data actions.

Hi Raghavendra, thank you for helping the review. I have just a concern about it. For the manager, returning "False" means: "I can not perform the migration, so please do it genericly using the host". While raising an exception, means: "I can do migration, but something went wrong in my storage/process".

From my point of view, we should only return "False" in scenarios where we do not support migration (Example: migration across cluster). In scenarios where we failed for some unexpected reason (like timeout or any bug in the code), we should treat as an error,  the user should fix its environment or/and report the bug. Otherwise, the user may keep using bug code/env.

Another issue, the move operation (migration between pools for iSCSI/FCP) might not be able to delete the migrated volume when failing. So, if we return "False" a second migration would start. 

There are some advantages of doing your approach, though. We can see how other drivers are doing and reach a consensus. I am just adding another point of view.

Sometimes we need to look at the bigger picture and provide some basic infrastructure code that will help other patches.

In this case we could look into expanding the `RequestContext` class to be able to have the action and the resource_type so that code deeper in the call chain can use it regardless of who is making the code.

Probably best if I give an example:

- We add `request_action` and `request_resource_type` fields to RequestContext and initialize them both to None.
- We add to cinder.messages.api.API a method called `create_from_context` (or some better name) that unlike the `create` method doesn't have a default for `action` or `resource_type` and uses the values available in the context, and if the context doesn't have the info then it doesn't create the message.
- Maybe we even create a decorator in cinder.messages to add the right values to `request_action` and `request_resource_type` in the `context`, or we do it at the beginning of the method.  We could go as far as adding the `id` of the resource to the context as well.
- Then for example in the `_connect_device` method we catch exceptions and call the new `create_from_context` method of the message API (we need to pass the context there).

This pattern would be useful for the attach/detach in the volume manager and will reduce the number of parameters we need to pass to create messages, since those 2 parameters will be in the context.

Thinking about this a bit more, I think we should discuss in tomorrow's IRC meeting what's the level of user messages we want to log, because maybe logging that what failed is the attach is too much information and your approach of less detailed error is better.

Hi Rajat, is the cleanup message really unnecessary in case you have another message created? I'm asking because the cleanup appears to be an independent operation that I understand it should work despite the result of the above ops. If the user get a error on backup_service.backup() and also on cleanup, only message BACKUP_CREATE_DRIVER_ERROR will be created.

This is done to avoid flooding the user with messages, if there is an error in both creating backup and cleanup, they should first fix the backup operation issue and execute it again (at least that's what my idea is while adding these messages). Also fixing the first issue might lead to automatically fixing the second issue as well. for eg: if a user gets error in backup create due to a temp volume/snapshot then fixing that would fix the cleanup as well. In summary, i don't feel it's a good idea to spam user with multiple messages and there should be only 1 error reason per operation.
Rajat, thanks for the explanation! Yes, that makes sense.
good point
This is clever, to pre-load the context and then all you have to do later is add the detail when you call the message_api.
probably no point passing the exception, you just created it so you know exactly what it is and what message detail you want to use.

Done
I added this to keep it consistent with the previous messages we have, but agree that it doesn't serve any purpose to the functionality here.

same here, you know what detail you want to provide, and if InvalidBackup is added to the mapping for some reason, you don't want the mapped message, you want backup_service_down.  So I think don't pass the exception.
Done

Is this really a concern?  (I mean, thinking about it like you have here is definitely good, but I'm wondering whether we'll ever actually see this.)  The message creation is in its own try block that catches an Exception and logs it (doesn't re-raise).  Plus we have unit tests that should at least catch a problem is the string template in the message_record is malformed or something.  Though looking at the code, it does mess around with timeutils and stuff before the try block.  Maybe the thing to do is to put everything in the create function into a big try block so we can guarantee that the message generation won't raise an exception.  That would make it easier to use, and I think that was the idea behind it catching Exception.  Let's see what Gorka thinks.
I haven't faced that in a practical usecase but Even if it is not a concern, the only change here is to move message_created = True after the message is created which IMO doesn't change anything.

Sure, but the idea behind the user messages is that they should be like a log message, that is, you just add a statement and don't have to think about it.  I don't like the idea of adding logic to handle these because it complicates the function for reasons that have nothing to do with the purpose of the function.  Plus, it's always possible for the logic to have a mistake in it, and it's better not to have to worry about that.

Sure, but my point is that I don't like adding extra logic to manage whether messages get produced or not in a function like this that has a completely different responsibility.  Is it possible to enhance the internal messages api so that it can detect multiple messages for the same event, and only store the first one?  I'd rather put effort into that, because then we can have the messages api unit tested thoroughly to be sure it works instead of individually testing each function to make sure the appropriate message is generated under various circumstances.

I believe it is a concern, and iirc I was the one who raised it in a previous patch.

If the RPC call to create the temporary device fails here, then it is likely that the call to cleanup temp resources (on L555) will also fail and we'll create both messages, which could be misleading for users, since the last error is consequence of the one happening here and irrelevant for the end user.

It all boils down to whether we want to report every individual error or just the root cause of the operation failure.

I think for users we should only report the initial one.

the more I think about this, the less I like the exception mapping.  It's supposedly designed for this situation, when we're catching an Exception that could be anything, but on the other hand, we know exactly what message detail we want to use.  So I think it's better not to pass the exception here (and probably throughout this file).

Done
Agree, We should consider refactoring existing messages in a patch to avoid this confusion.

I guess I wasn't clear on any of my comments!  I was talking about removing the exception mapping (not removing the possibility of passing exceptions) because an exception in the mapping will override the passed message detail, and the only way to prevent that is to not pass the exception.  It would be easier if we could be consistent and not think about it, so for example, we could change the logic so the mapping is only used if no message detail is passed, which actually is more intuitive  and is probably how most people think this feature works.  Then you just pass whatever you have available to the messages api and let it sort out what to do.

I like the idea of passing the exceptions, because it allows us to expand, in the future, the message api to store the exception traceback and make it only visible to administrators.

But now I see that Rajat already removed it on the next patch, so no reason to add it again now.

I agree.  The original design sounds like it would be useful, but we should re-assess the locations where an exception is passed to see whether it makes sense or not.  And if it doesn't make sense in any of the current locations, then we should just remove it, because it confuses developers, and the idea behind user messages is that they should be easy to add and you shouldn't have to think about them.

zuul_registry/main.py.message: Having said that, I don't think we should delete the layer; we have no indication that there's anything wrong with that blob.  It was uploaded with a content digest and we validated it already.  It's the manifest that's wrong.

I think there is a possible race between simultaneous uploads for the same image and deleting these blobs. In the storage layer we would check a simple lock mechanism to ensure we don't have multiple writers at the same time; however, I worry that simple mechanism is too simple to negotiate for these deletions.

This race may manifest as the blobs already being deleted when we try to delete them here (because the other upload is tripping over the same verification problem). In the case of filesystem storage we do check that the path exists before attempting to delete it, but there is a small period of time where a context switch could happen between checking existence and attempting the delete which would result in an error being raised.

The other way I think this can show up is if one uploader fails the strict check and the other does not. In that case we could potentially delete the upload out from under the successfully verified uploader.

That said if the docker protocol mandates that the layers all be uploaded prior to the manifest (somewhat implied by the size checking above) then we would avoid this race entirely as any subsequent uploads would have stopped prior to any manifest checking. It would be good if someone else can double check this.
Manifest upload should only happen after the layers are uploaded, per https://docs.docker.com/registry/spec/api/#pushing-an-image
In that case I think we avoid this race entirely because additional uploads would have stopped executing before they tried to write the manifest.

cinder/api/v3/snapshots.py.message:
-1: This code will ignore the caller passing force set to false.

I think we should be consistent.  We either ignore the force parameter in this microversion, or we just default to true on L140 for this microversion and to false for earlier versions.

I was going to complain about this being mostly duplicate code from v2, but since v2 is going away, I think it's OK to have this code here.

I'm not sure what you mean by it ignoring the caller passing force=False.  Are you suggesting that someone passing force=False should fail when snapshotting an in-use volume, even after this API change?  I'm not sure I agree, but we should define this in the spec.

I think the model for v3 API controllers like this has typically been to copy the needed methods from the v2 controller and add what is needed for the new functionality?  I'm not sure what would work better...

nit: Why do we explicitly check for it not being None here?   If it's None then it's not an str instance.

nit: Why are we nested the 2 ifs instead of having a single boolean expression?
-1: false is not the only possible value indicating force is disabled, we also have 'off', 'no', 'f', '0', and 'n'.

I still prefer setting the force parameter instead of adding a new one, but you already explained your reasons for the new parameter, so we just won't agree of this one.  This comment won't affect the vote.

If someone has 'force=major', this will raise a ValueError with a message (that I think will be passed through to the user): "Unrecognized value 'major', acceptable values are: 't','true', 'on', 'y', 'yes', '1', 'f', 'false', 'off', 'n', 'no', or '0'" [0].  I wonder whether we should do a try here, catch a ValueError, and in the except block check the mv.  If it's pre-3.65, just reraise the ValueError, and if it's >=3.65, change the message to something like "Since microversion 3.65 the 'force' flag is invalid for this request.  For backward compatability, however, when the 'force' flag is passed with a value evaluating to True, it is silently ignored."

We'll still have to do that secondary check at lines 147-150, but could re-use the above message in the exception.

(This would also help address the weirdness Fernando mentions below.)

[0] https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.utils/src/commit/cf45c2cf8a9ac7308cf425a8c5263314cc398dc9/oslo_utils/strutils.py#L152-L154

I'm wrong about strict=True raising here because a non-boolean-ish value will be caught by the request validation schema.  So Eric's correct that we just need to screen for False for mv.SNAPSHOT_IN_USE below.

Why not be strict and raise on an ambiguous force flag value?

If user chooses to use force flag, they should put in a valid value. And I think it should be assumed that all previously hardcoded usages of force flag (for which this backward compatibility is for) use a valid value there.

A force flag that can't be set to False seems a bit weird =x
Wouldn't be simpler just ignore the force flag in case of vers 3.65 (SNAPSHOT_IN_USE)? Is the idea to keep the API consistent and avoid users from getting a force behavior even with force flag set to false?

@Fernando: Yes, that's exactly it.  The behavior with 3.65 is that if you request a snapshot, it gets made.  We're accepting force=True for backward compatibility with scripts that already have 'force=True' hard-coded.  But force=False seems to mean "don't make the snapshot if you have to force it", so rather than ignore the flag, we reject the request and let the user think it over.

The logic and discussion make sense. I just want to suggest improving the user-facing message on the same line:

explanation='Invalid value %s for force flag.' % force)

This seems to suggest an invalid value for the force flag.

If im understanding this correctly, at this point the intended force param is already understood from the force_flag, and rather, the issue is that we are telling the user that we failed the operation because he set force to false. So, I think the message should read something like:

Snapshot is in-use, and "force" is explicitly set to False - aborting..
Don't think there is supposed to be an 'f' here.

cinder/volume/api.py.message:
I'm not sure which one of the options is better:

- Adding a new parameter like this patch is doing
- Use the `force` parameter for this case as well
- Renaming the force parameter to `allow_in_use`

I kind of like the last one best, though it will probably make for a bigger patch, which goes in line with what you've been saying for the past 5 years about "force" being ambiguous.

Reusing of the force parameter is also appealing because it creates less code changes, doesn't duplicate parameters that do the same thing, and it's an easy concept "force is always set to true".

I don't love the idea of having both "force" and "allow_in_use" parameters, but wouldn't necessarily downvote for it.

Some of this needs to be discussed in
    https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder-specs/+/781914/

I leaned toward separating "force" and "allow_in_use" because force is provided by the API caller, allow_in_use is just added by the API code itself and isn't sent by the caller.
